metadata.sermon_start_end: There’s a sense in which the history of the Christian church can be described as a history of thoroughgoing confusion about who we are and what we are called to do. It’s not a very edifying spectacle. We can all make long lists of the various wrong ideas [...] Together we receive his very self for this Advent life. We may return to our posts with gladness, having been fed and upheld by the One Who Comes. Rejoice, rejoice! Emmanuel shall come to thee, O Israel. Amen.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon centers on the parable of the doorkeeper. However, it leans heavily on the general theme of 'Advent' and 'identity crisis' rather than extracting what is unique to Mark 13:33-37 compared to other parables of watchfulness (like Matthew 25). The 'nowhere else' quality is thin.
quotes: It is the Gospel for the first Sunday in Advent, the parable of the doorkeeper.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Isolate the specific Marcan emphasis on the 'authority' (exousia) given to the servants which distinguishes this text from mere waiting.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: Exegesis is minimal. There is a brief mention of the first-century context and the 'young Christian church,' but it lacks engagement with the original languages or the specific theological structure of Mark's Gospel. It treats the text more as a 'story' than a document requiring rigorous exposition.
quotes: Come back with me into the very first century AD when the Gospel of Mark was being put together.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the Greek nuance of 'agrypneite' (staying awake/sleeplessness) and the specific historical pressure of the Roman-Jewish war context to ground the 'crisis' in history rather than just modern sociology.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is strong and concrete regarding the 'zeitgeist.' It identifies specific modern anxieties (church decline, secularization) and uses a very concrete personal anecdote to illustrate the 'stranger' at the door.
quotes: The world is knocking more insistently on those church doors... Some are thieves and murderers. Many are desperately poor and starving.
I was in Grand Central Terminal getting ready to take the train home to Westchester.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Avoid the 'Lady Bountiful' psychological focus and pivot more toward the 'two ways'—the actual consequence of the church failing its watch.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a somewhat traditional block structure: sociological introduction, then the text, then a personal story. The 'mixing' Dekker demands is present in the middle, but the sermon starts too far from the text.
quotes: Perhaps you begin to feel the tension in the atmosphere of this parable.
The Lord came to me in a most unexpected guise.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Start with the text immediately to allow the exposition to 'expound' the hearer from the first minute.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery is well-articulated as the 'absence of God' and the 'darkness in our world.' Redemption is found in Christ's coming. Gratitude is framed as 'watching for signs.' However, it risks being too psychological.
quotes: the season in which the church looks straight down into its own heart and finds there—the absence of God.
The Lord has come—he will come.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Sharpen the 'misery' from a 'crisis of identity' to a 'misery before God' (coram Deo).

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon mentions the 'battle line' and 'falling away,' but it lacks the sharp edge of Dekker's 'two ways.' The possibility of being truly 'lost' (temporal or eternal) is softened by the focus on 'identity crisis.'
quotes: No wonder there are so many who fall away; the church is located precisely where the battle line is drawn.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Explicitly address the consequence of the Master finding the doorkeeper asleep. What is lost if the church fails?

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The sermon correctly identifies the two natures (King in glory vs. stranger) and points to the sacrament as the source of grace outside the self.
quotes: The one Lord who is central in the sermon is Christ.
He will come in the future, not as a stranger, but as the King in his glory.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure the 'One Lord' is not just a 'guise' in the poor, but the sovereign God who judges and saves.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 14.5 minutes (1450 words), the sermon falls short of Dekker’s 20-minute minimum. It lacks the 'breadth' required for 'depth.'
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical section (Thesis 2) to provide the necessary theological weight to reach the 20-minute threshold.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon is too short and lacks sufficient exegetical depth to meet Dekker's standard. It relies heavily on sociological observation and personal anecdote rather than the 'recreation' of the specific Bible passage into a current word. While the Christological focus is adequate, the 'two ways' are insufficiently sharp.
strengths: Concrete application to the American cultural context and the 'zeitgeist' of church decline.
Strong Christocentric conclusion that points to the sacrament as a means of grace.
Effective use of the 'Advent' tension between the 'already' and 'not yet'.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (under 20 minutes) prevents the necessary 'breadth' for theological depth.
Weak exegesis; the preacher does not demonstrate the required 'knowledge of Hebrew and Greek' or original context.
The 'two ways' (the seriousness of being lost) are not sufficiently thematic.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a meaningful address, but it is not yet a 'sermon' in the strict sense of Dekker’s theses. It functions more as a theological meditation on the state of the church than a rigorous exposition and application of Mark 13.
